summary: The text discusses the increasing fame of a figure who resurrected from the dead, leading to widespread recognition across the world. Because of this, some sought to destroy this figure's soul, prioritizing earthly matters over themselves, which is likened to descending into the earth. This is connected to threats from Roman leaders Titus and Vespasian, referred to as foxes due to their cunning nature. The text also draws parallels with Herod, described as a fox in the Bible, and touches upon Jews' allegiance to Caesar, illustrating their subjugation under Roman rule.
